message_1: Let X and Y be topological spaces such that X is homeomorphic to $S^2$, the 2-dimensional sphere. Compute $\pi_1(X\times Y)$, the fundamental group of the product space $X\times Y$ with respect to some basepoint.
message_2:
Since X is homeomorphic to $S^2$, we can assume that X is $S^2$. Now, we want to compute the fundamental group of the product space $S^2 \times Y$. 

Recall the following theorem: If X and Y are topological spaces, then $\pi_1(X \times Y) \cong \pi_1(X) \times \pi_1(Y)$.

In our case, X is $S^2$. The fundamental group of $S^2$ is trivial, i.e., $\pi_1(S^2) = \{e\}$, where e is the identity element. This is because $S^2$ is simply connected, meaning it is connected and every loop can be continuously deformed to a point.

Now, we can apply the theorem:

$\pi_1(S^2 \times Y) \cong \pi_1(S^2) \times \pi_1(Y) \cong \{e\} \times \pi_1(Y)$.

Since the direct product of a trivial group with any group G is isomorphic to G itself, we have:

$\pi_1(S^2 \times Y) \cong \pi_1(Y)$.

So, the fundamental group of the product space $S^2 \times Y$ is isomorphic to the fundamental group of Y.
